I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) seeks to achieve 
economic growth, reduce poverty, and graduate from its least-developed-country status by 2020. 
The National Growth and Poverty Eradication Strategy (NGPES), approved by the National 
Assembly in October 2003, provides a broad strategic framework that emphasizes the need to 
build capacity at all levels of public administration, and particularly to improve public financial 
management (PFM), to achieve the socially inclusive development goals laid out in the sixth 
National Socio-Economic Development Plan (NSEDP) and the NGPES.1 To strengthen its PFM 
capacity in line with the country’s policy and development priorities, the Government has lodged 
its  reform  strategy  in  the  5-year  Public  Expenditure  Management  Strengthening  Program 
(PEMSP), which it adopted in November 2005. The strategic objective of the PEMSP is to 
improve the efficient use of public resources and to strengthen the overall transparency of and 
accountability  for  public  spending.  The  2007  Public  Expenditure  Review  and  Integrated 
Fiduciary Assessment underlined the importance of efficient public expenditure management 
(PEM) in meeting the Government’s poverty reduction goals.2  
2.  At the Government’s request, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) intends to provide 
technical assistance (TA) to support the Government in improving its PEM. 3 The proposed TA 
conforms  to  ADB’s  country  strategy  and  program  2007–2011  for  the  Lao  PDR,4 which 
emphasizes  good  governance  through  policy  and  institutional  development  to  achieve 
sustainable  economic  growth.  A  Fact-Finding  Mission  to  Vientiane  from  30  January  to 
4 February  2008  discussed  and  reached  an  understanding  with  representatives  of  the 
Government on the TA objectives, scope, cost, and implementation arrangements. The design 
and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  For the Government to succeed in implementing the NGPES and the NSEDP, it will 
have  to  mobilize  resources  effectively  and  allocate  them  efficiently.  Given  the  close  links 
between policy and resources in PEM, ADB has provided institutional support to the Lao PDR 
since 1998,5 particularly the accounting department under the Ministry of Finance (MOF). ADB 
has helped develop and implement improved government accounting regulations, as well as a 
                                                 
1 PFM  comprises  all  the  upstream  (preparation  and  programming)  and  downstream  components  (execution, 
accounting, control, reporting, monitoring, and evaluation) of budgeting, together with the legal and organizational 
framework  and  arrangements.  PFM  systems  also  include  revenue  management  and  are  often  used 
interchangeably with PEM systems. 
2  World Bank, International Monetary Fund, ADB, and European Union. 2007. Lao PDR: Public Expenditure Review, 
Integrated Fiduciary Assessment. Washington, DC.  
3  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 3 March 2008. 
4  ADB. 2006. Lao People’s Democratic Republic: Country  Strategy and Program 2007-2011. Manila. 
5  Several TA projects—ADB. 1998. Technical Assistance to the Lao People’s Democratic Republic for Establishing 
the National Audit Office. Manila (TA 2987-LAO); ADB. 2001. Technical Assistance to the Lao People’s Democratic 
Republic for Institutional Strengthening of the National Audit Office. Manila (TA 3771-LAO); ADB. 2003. Technical 
Assistance to the Lao People’s Democratic Republic for Enhancing Government Accounting Regulations and 
Procedures Phase II. Manila (TA 4180-LAO); ADB. 2005. Technical Assistance to the Lao People’s Democratic 
Republic for Public Expenditure Planning for National Growth and Poverty Eradication Strategy. Manila (TA 4627-
LAO); and ADB. 2007. Technical Assistance to the Lao People’s Democratic Republic for Improved Public 
Financial Management Systems. Manila (TA 4954-LAO)—are now being implemented to (i) extend the coverage of 
the government financial information system to 38 districts in the municipalities of Luang Prabang, Champassak, 
and Vientiane; and (ii) formulate a strategy and pilot-test the first-ever consolidated statement of financial position 
of the Government.

2 
database management system (the government financial information system, or GFIS), which 
automates the capture of data consistent with a standardized chart of accounts and facilitates 
more timely budget report preparation.6 ADB also supported the creation of the State Audit 
Organization (SAO) and later the drafting of the Audit Law in 2006, which made the SAO 
independent from the Prime Minister’s Office and mandated it to report its audit findings and 
audit opinions to the National Assembly, the President of the Lao PDR, and the Prime Minister’s 
Office. The Nam Theun 2 Revenue Management Arrangements (NT2 RMA) were based on that 
early ADB assistance.7  
4.  Since the PEMSP was first implemented in 2005, the Government has made steady 
progress in putting in place a sound PEM framework. A new Organic Law was passed in 
November 2006 and the MOF was reorganized to deal with the newly centralized departments 
of customs, tax, and treasury. The GFIS is being upgraded to identify, track, and monitor budget 
execution, and track expenditure. The Government will thus be able to manage its budgetary 
resources more effectively and with greater transparency. The new chart of accounts, consistent 
with  the  IMF  Government  Financial  Statistics  and  international  public  sector  accounting 
standards, is expected to be used for the FY2008 budget. With the Medium-Term Expenditure 
Framework (MTEF) and Medium-Term Fiscal Framework (MTFF) models, developed with ADB 
TA support, the budgeting framework has been strengthened.8    
5.  Under  TA  4627,  a  strategy  and  a  manual  for  an  MTEF  for  all  line  ministries  and 
provinces  and  indicative  MTEFs  for  the  education  and  health  subsectors  (e.g.,  primary 
education and expansion of rural health infrastructure) were prepared. The MTEF process, 
though firmly anchored in budget preparation and the aggregate spending ceiling (derived from 
the MTFF), will improve fiscal planning and budgeting only over the medium term (through 
spending that is better aligned with NSEDP objectives and is more cost-effective). But it has yet 
to become operational.  
6.  Despite all the ADB support, however, aligning public expenditure policies with pro-poor 
NSEDP priorities remains a challenge for Lao PDR. Besides severe capacity constraints, the 
Government lacks realistic fiscal forecasts, a mechanism for ensuring that provincial budgets 
reflect  national  priorities,  a  unified  budget  process  (rather  than  fragmented  budgeting,  by 
institution and by type of expenditure), and a more normal, less compressed budget cycle. The 
MTEF will help improve the budget process and outcomes by clarifying policy objectives and 
making budget allocations more predictable, the coverage more comprehensive, and the use of 
resources more transparent.  
7.  Adopting and implementing the MTEF will be a long-term endeavor and will require 
policy  officials  and  technical  staff  to  buy  into  and  commit  to  continuous  improvement. 
                                                 
6  The GFIS, the first nationwide automation project of the MOF, was developed and is being implemented with 
assistance from ADB. 
7  Nam Theun 2 Hydroelectric Project: Implementation Policy Framework, issued by the Deputy Prime Minister of the 
Lao People’s Democratic to ADB, 7 March 2005. The Government’s commitment to implement all activities 
required under the PEMSP is also among the specific assurances given by the Government for the Nam Theun 2 
(NT2) Project, ADB. 2005. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on a Proposed 
Loan  to  the  Lao  People’s  Democratic  Republic  for  the  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  for  the  Nam  Theun  2 
Hydroelectric Project. Manila (Loan 2162-LAO, approved on 4 April, para. 83[ix]). According to the NT2 RMA, SAO 
will publish, starting in FY2009, an audit opinion on the statement of receipts and transfers for the NT2 revenue 
account, covering the financial statements of eligible programs, and attest to the use of NT2 funds for eligible 
programs. 
8  TA 4627-Lao: Public Expenditure Planning for National Growth and Poverty Eradication Strategy was approved in 
2005 to assist in developing and pilot-testing the MTFF and the MTEF. The MTEF contains estimates of the cost of 
delivering existing programs (approved by the Government) over the medium term, consistent with the fiscal 
strategy presented in the MTFF. The 3-year MTEF centers on policy priorities and supports decisions about the 
level and allocation of resources, both government-wide and within individual spending agencies.

3
Knowledge and applied skills in macroeconomics and public expenditure management will be 
developed. TA in support of this critical area is needed to reinforce and build on the ongoing 
PFM initiatives—implementation of the revised chart of accounts and budget classification, 
centralization of the treasury, strengthening of external audit, further GFIS updating, and efforts 
to establish internal controls and internal audit. The proposed TA and other, complementary 
support measures under PEMSP will address the severe capacity constraints and skill gaps in 
budget planning, budget execution, accounting, reporting, and auditing. Improvements must be 
made in these areas—allocations must be linked to policy, expenditure, and public finance 
reporting for efficient budget outcomes—to strengthen public spending for poverty reduction.  
8.  Progress  in  implementing  PEMSP  will  allow  the  Government  to  meet  its  specific 
commitments under the revenue management arrangements for the Nam Theun 2 and other 
revenue-earning projects and will help reduce poverty in the country. The challenge lies in the 
degree of the Government’s commitment to overall PFM reform, especially through the adoption 
of international good practices. The proposed TA will support more coordinated programming, 
the  strengthening  and  increased  use  of  national  systems,  and  the  adoption  of  common 
procedures  and  harmonized  activities  by  development  partners,  in  line  with  the  Vientiane 
Declaration on Aid Effectiveness.9  
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9  The TA will strengthen PFM in Lao PDR to enable the country to reduce poverty and 
help it to achieve the Millennium Development Goals. Its outcome will be efficient resource 
allocation within and between sectors, with more predictable budgets and greater accountability 
for expenditure in selected ministries, based on the Government’s socioeconomic programs and 
benchmarked against international good practice standards in PFM. 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  Institutional Assessment and Diagnostic Review. The TA will involve reviewing and 
assessing progress made toward overall PFM reforms, and identifying institutional constraints 
on the implementation of PEMSP reform measures by the Executing Agency (EA) and the 
Implementing Agencies (IAs), taking into account the intergovernmental fiscal policy measures 
carried out in recent years. The gap analysis will cover selected provinces.  
11.  Implementation  of  MTFF  and  MTEF  in  Selected  Ministries,  Consistent  with 
Existing Methodological Framework. The present fiscal planning process, including progress 
in the budget management process, will be assessed. Challenges and opportunities will be 
identified and addressed in the implementation of the Budget Law and in the drafting of the 
implementing decrees and related ministerial instructions, and improvements will be made in the 
methodological  framework  of  the  MTFF  and  MTEF  models  already  developed.  Specific 
technical and policy issues in the implementation of the MTFF and MTEF framework for all 
                                                 
9  The Vientiane Declaration’s Action Plan on Aid Effectiveness, an agreed road map for more effective development 
assistance, was endorsed by the Government of Lao PDR and development partners in May 2007. The declaration 
builds on the key themes of the Paris Declaration, which has been endorsed by ADB and other development 
partners. The Paris Declaration underscores three critical PFM challenges in Lao PDR—harmonization of donor 
assistance,  alignment  of  donor  assistance  with  government-owned  reform  programs,  and  effective  capacity 
development over the long term.

4 
ministries  and  provinces  (including  agreeing  on  data,  assumptions,  parameters,  and  the 
structure of the model; updating and reprioritizing procedures and baseline projections over the 
medium term) will be identified and addressed. An indicative MTEF will be formulated for other 
priority  sectors  (Ministry  of  Agriculture  [MOA]  and  Ministry  of  Public  Works  and  Transport 
[MPW&T]). The TA will also support the establishment of an institutional framework in the form 
of an interministerial technical working group, as recommended in the draft action plan prepared 
under TA 4627-LAO for strengthening budget management practices (footnote 8). The MTEF 
will be implemented on a pilot basis in the Ministry of Finance and selected line ministries. Staff 
capacity, data availability, and other practical implementation matters will be considered in the 
selection of the ministries.  
12.  Implementation  of  a  Capacity  Development  Road  Map.  The  fiscal  policy  and 
personnel departments of the MOF will be assisted in formulating and implementing a long-term 
capacity development plan for the central ministries (MOF and selected line ministries) and 
selected provincial finance departments, to improve PFM capacities as needed for budget 
planning, which will include working with MTFF and MTEF methodology. Besides training in the 
effective implementation of the MTFF and MTEF models, the capacity development plan will 
include  training  in  generic  PFM  techniques  (budgetary  systems,  international  PFM/PEM 
standards, budget planning, budget execution, budget monitoring, and reporting). Training in 
macroeconomics, public finance, fiscal planning, and change management will also be given. In 
addition, training in information technology (IT), to enable government staff to use computer 
spreadsheets and database management models, will be covered by the TA. Participatory and 
“action  learning”  or  “learning  by  doing”  approaches  will  be  used.  Besides,  study  tours  for 
selected key functionaries to neighboring countries undertaking similar reforms will be proposed 
to enable these officials to exchange experiences and learn from the successes with similar 
systems in these countries. Seminars will be conducted and civil servants will be trained to act 
as facilitators. The TA will make use of the training infrastructure of MOF and the resources of 
academic institutions to ensure the sustainability of the capacity development efforts.  
13.  Open  forums,  seminars,  and  conferences,  with  representatives  from  the  National 
Assembly, the Ministry of Planning and Investment (MPI), MOF, sector ministries, and provinces 
participating, will strengthen the policy dialogue and facilitate in-depth discussions on PFM and 
governance issues. Eminent persons and high-level representatives from selected countries, 
the Public Expenditure and Financial Accountability Secretariat, multilateral development banks, 
and development partners will also be invited to the open forums. 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The  total  cost  of  the  TA  is  estimated  at  $1.2  million.  ADB  will  provide  a  grant  of 
$1.1 million from its TA funding program. The Government will finance the balance of $100,000 
by providing counterpart staff, office space, utilities, and physical facilities. Appendix 2 gives the 
cost estimates and financing plan. 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The MOF, principally through its fiscal policy, personnel, and budget departments, will be 
the EA. The planning and budget departments of MOA, MOE, MOH, MPW&T, and MPI will be 
the IAs. The PEMSP coordination mechanisms will be used to facilitate the review of TA

5
implementation progress in the overall context of the PEMSP.10 The project director for the 
proposed TA will be nominated by the vice minister of finance. 
16.  The TA will be implemented over 24 months, from June 2008 to May 2010, and will 
require a team of two international specialists (17 person-months) in PEM and PFM, and two 
national experts (32 person-months) in fiscal management and software development, working 
intermittently over the TA implementation period. The consultants will be hired through a firm 
following quality- and cost-based selection and the submission of simplified technical proposals, 
and according to ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to 
time). The firm will provide overall project management oversight over the consultants’ output. 
The  consulting  team  will  produce  various  reports  and  plans  as  outlined  in  their  terms  of 
reference, which will be discussed in tripartite meetings and approved by the Government. The 
team will perform the functions of a project management unit and provide technical PFM advice, 
including ongoing functional and IT support. Desktop computers, printers for user departments, 
and laptops for project coordinators identified by the EA and the IAs will be provided to assist in 
project implementation and to enable the sharing of a common database within the EA and IAs 
during project implementation. ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to 
time) will be applied in procuring IT and other assets for this project. All equipment certified by 
the  consultants  will  be  turned  over  to  the  EA  according  to  ADB  procedures  after  the 
implementation period. The TA will support joint review and monitoring by ADB and government 
agencies  for  effective  implementation,  including  regular  consultations  with  all  stakeholders 
through participatory workshops and seminars, to build consensus and government ownership 
of the outputs of the TA. There will also be close coordination with external funding agencies 
involved in the PEMSP. A public and government-wide awareness campaign will be organized 
to promote understanding of the importance of this work and to cope effectively with change 
management issues. Outline terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S RECOMMENDATION  
17.  The President recommends that the Board approve the provision of technical assistance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $1,100,000 on a grant basis to the Government of Lao PDR for 
Strengthening Public Financial Management. 
                                                 
10 The PEMSP implementation arrangements include (i) a PEMSP program steering committee, chaired by the vice 
minister of finance and with representatives from the relevant MOF departments, which reviews progress and 
approves work programs for the implementation of the PEMSP components; and (ii) a PEMSP implementation 
committee, chaired by the deputy director general of the fiscal policy department and supported by a full-time 
PEMSP secretariat.

10  Appendix 3     
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
A.  International Consultants 
1.  International  Budget  Planning  and  Public  Expenditure  Management/Team 
Leader (12 person-months, Intermittent)  
1.  The team leader will have at least 15 years of substantive professional experience in the 
Ministry of Finance across a wide range of functions (expenditure planning, budgeting, treasury, 
and  accounting)  and  at  least  10  years  of  work,  in  leadership  and  advisory  roles,  in  public 
expenditure  reform  and  capacity-building  programs  preferably  in  transition  economies  and  in 
Southeast Asia. The team leader will demonstrate a sound understanding of the history and 
evolution of public financial management (PFM) reforms and of PFM capacity development in a 
developing member country. The team leader must have at least a master’s degree or equivalent 
in one of the following fields: (i) economics; (ii) public administration and policy; (iii) public financial 
management, and should be sensitive to the cultural and political context of the Lao People’s 
Democratic Republic (Lao PDR). The team leader will be responsible for submitting the work plan 
and various reports on time to the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the Government, and for 
obtaining the requisite approvals from the Public Expenditure Management Strengthening Program 
(PEMSP) steering committee and implementation committee. The team leader will be responsible 
for all outputs of the technical assistance (TA) and will guide all consultants in undertaking the 
activities listed in the design and monitoring framework. In performing this task, the team leader will 
build on the work already done under TA 4627-LAO: Public Expenditure Planning for National 
Growth  and  Poverty  Eradication  Strategy,  2005–2007  (footnote  8),  which  established  the 
methodological framework for the Medium-Term Fiscal Framework (MTFF) and Medium-Term 
Expenditure Framework (MTEF) process. 
2.  The  team  leader  will  (i)  hold  extensive  discussions  with  Ministry  of  Finance  (MOF) 
department representatives (from the fiscal policy department, the lead department in PEMSP 
implementation; the budget department; and the personnel department), representatives of the 
Ministry of Planning and Investment (MPI) and selected sector ministries and provinces (planning 
and  finance  departments)  and  the  Bank  of  the  Lao  PDR  (BOL),  and  development  partners; 
(ii)   coordinate  closely  with  the  project  director  of  the  Executing  Agency  (EA)  and  project 
coordinators in the Implementing Agencies (IAs); and (iii) travel to the selected provinces and 
districts as needed. The specific tasks of the team leader will include the following:  
(i)  Conducting an institutional review and diagnostic assessment of the major issues 
and  challenges  in  the  public  budgetary  system  of  the  Lao  PDR,  including  its 
regulatory,  institutional,  and  legal  framework.  This  diagnostic  and  gap  analysis 
report will extend to the political economy aspects of the budgeting process across 
all levels of government, and will include a review of the Budget Law, the budget 
classification system and chart of accounts, fiscal expenditure assignment and fiscal 
transfer options, and the findings and recommendations of the international PFM 
and fiscal planning specialist. The diagnostic report, incorporating the output of the 
international PFM and fiscal planning specialist, will be due by the second month of 
TA implementation and will be discussed with all stakeholders. 
(ii)  Designing  and  implementing  a  series  of  extensive  capacity  development  and 
training  programs,  workshops,  and  seminars,  in  accordance  with  a  capacity 
development  and  training  plan  based  on  the  PEMSP  and  MTFF  and  MTEF 
requirements, to enhance the capacity of government staff at the central level (MOF, 
MPI, Ministry of Agriculture [MOA], Ministry of Education [MOE], Ministry of Health 
[MOH], Ministry of Public Works and Transport [MPW&T], BOL and in selected

Appendix 3  11 
provincial finance departments, in the context of the budget management exercise; 
and  creating  a  general  awareness  of  international  PFM/PEM  good  practice 
standards  and  of  the  principles  of  PFM,  macroeconomics,  public  finance,  and 
change management.   
(iii)  Designing capacity and skills improvement indicators at the start of the training 
programs and monitoring these throughout TA implementation; gathering baseline 
data on staff skills and levels of skill, to provide the starting point for tracking 
capacity improvement; and supporting on-the-job training for relevant staff. 
(iv)  Preparing  resource  materials  for  (classroom  and  on-the-job)  training,  and  for 
workshops and seminars. 
(v)  Building on the achievements of the earlier TA 4627-LAO that established the MTFF 
and MTEF methodology for MOF, MOE, and MOH, preparing simple operational 
guidelines  (relating  to  the  budget  process)  in  support  of  the  MTFF  and  MTEF 
process, including,, among others, the following: 
(a)  agreeing on data, assumptions, parameters, and the structure of the MTEF 
model, and updating and reprioritizing procedures and ultimately the initial 
baseline projections over the medium term for all ministries and provincial 
governments; 
(b)  aligning  the  budget  structure  and  expenditure  classifications  (including 
recurrent  and  capital expenditures)  with  the  new  chart  of  accounts;  this 
activity includes reviewing the present budget classification and proposing 
improvements  to  further  align  this  with  international  good  public  budget 
management standards; 
(c)  providing the mechanism for evaluating expenditure impact, which will form 
the basis for expenditure reallocation and prospective annual and 3-year 
rolling budgets; 
(d)  presenting budget data on a gross basis, with expenditure classified into 
economic, functional, and administrative categories according to the new 
chart of accounts; 
(e)  producing an improved expenditure budget document, which includes the 
fiscal policy objectives, the macroeconomic framework, a statement of policy 
priorities, and fiscal risks; and 
(f)  supporting  the  PEMSP  steering  committee  in  establishing  a  technical 
working  group  to  address  technical  PFM  issues  and  to  implement  the 
activities recommended in the draft action plan submitted under the earlier 
TA 4627-LAO. 
(vi)  Assisting MOF, MOE, MOH, MOA, and MPW&T, as well as BOL, in implementing 
the  MTFF  and  MTEF  (on  a  pilot  basis),  and  refining  the  MTFF  and  MTEF 
frameworks for full-fledged MTEFs in key priority areas before the completion of the 
TA, in coordination with the PEMSP implementation committee. 
(vii)  Providing continuing technical advice on PFM and assisting the Government in 
developing a budget preparation and reporting template and forms, in line with 
international best practice, and updating the budget preparation manual, according 
to the new Budget Law and implementing decrees and international best practices; 
assisting in the development of norms that can be used to help link budgets more

12  Appendix 3 
closely to objectives (e.g., minimum nonwage recurrent spending per school student, 
minimum maintenance expenditure as a percentage of the value of capital assets).  
(viii)  Assisting the Government in drafting implementing decrees in areas to be mutually 
identified,  especially  to  ensure  coherence  between  the  proposed  MTFF  MTEF 
processes and the Budget Law. 
(ix)  Procuring  equipment  according  to  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines  (2007,  as 
amended from time to time). 
(x)  Overseeing the sustainability of the existing automated budget management models     
and budget databases, and refining the MTEF software model. 
(xi)  Drafting the agenda for open forums, and assisting in identifying resource persons 
and  in  planning  and  organizing  the  open  forums  in  coordination  with  the 
Government and ADB. 
(xii)  Preparing the following reports and written outputs (in both English and Lao): an 
inception report, a midterm report, a draft final report, and a final report. Each of 
these will be discussed in tripartite meetings. The inception report, to be submitted 
within a month of the fielding of consultants, will define the activities, timelines, and 
the intended results of the TA, including the plans for the workshops, study tours 
and training series. The midterm report on the progress of TA activities versus the 
intended outcomes and outputs of the design and monitoring framework will be 
submitted within 12 months of the approval of the inception report. The draft final 
report will be submitted at least 4 weeks before the completion of the TA. The final 
report,  incorporating  comments  from  the  Government  and  ADB,  lessons  to  be 
learned,  and  the  difficulties  encountered,  and  identifying  areas  where  future 
programs will be most effective in assisting the Government, should be submitted 
upon the completion of the services.  
(xiii)  Taking specific care that the measurement mechanisms, designed outputs, and 
indicative targets are included in the monitoring and reporting of TA implementation 
progress. A strategic approach to gathering baseline information and its subsequent 
measurement should be included in the TA inception report where no measurement 
is in place, or no baseline information is available. 
(xiv)  Assessing the financial management capacity of the Executing Agency (MOF) and 
the Implementing Agencies in accordance with ADB’s Financial Management and 
Analysis of Project guidelines. 
(xv)   Conducting a policy dialogue with senior MOF management (including the vice 
minister of finance) and performing additional tasks required, including assisting 
ADB  missions,  to  help  achieve  the  goals  and  objectives  of  the  TA  within  the 
approved budget. 
(xvi)   Conducting  extensive  participatory  discussions  and  organizing  study  tours  and 
workshops with stakeholders to build consensus and ownership on the frameworks 
and automated models. 
2.  Public Financial Management and Fiscal Planning (5 person-months, intermittent) 
3.  The  public  financial  management  and  fiscal  planning  specialist  will  have  substantial 
knowledge and deep understanding of various aspects of PFM and a minimum experience of 15 
years in budget planning, budget formulation, budget execution, budget reporting and monitoring, 
public expenditure management, and accountability frameworks, in the context of international

Appendix 3  13 
PFM standards. The specialist will demonstrate a sound understanding of the history and evolution 
of PFM reforms in a developing member country and will also (i) have demonstrated experience in 
capacity  development  and  change  management  in  developing  countries  and  transitional 
economies, preferably within the region; and (ii) have at least a master’s degree or equivalent in 
one of the following fields: (i) economics, (ii) public administration and policy, and (iii) public 
financial management, and should be sensitive to the cultural and political context of Lao PDR. 
The specialist will report to the team leader and will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  Preparing  an  assessment  of  relevant  current  and  planned  activities  of  the 
Government  of  the  Lao  PDR  and  other  major  stakeholders,  including  external 
funding agencies, under the PEMSP, in the context of the overall PFM programs 
and the measures undertaken to establish the implementation system for Nam 
Theun 2 Revenue Management Arrangements, within 2 months of the start of TA 
implementation. 
(ii)  Identifying major challenges and opportunities related to the current fiscal planning 
and  expenditure  framework,  including  reviewing  the  Budget  Law,  budget 
classification systems and chart of accounts, and fiscal relationships following the 
centralization of the treasury, tax, and customs functions by the Government. The 
assessment will include accountability processes and institutional arrangements for 
accomplishing  the  key  objectives  of  the  PFM  reforms  in  MOF,  selected  line 
ministries, and finance departments in selected provinces. The diagnostics and gap 
analysis should be submitted within 2 months of this consultant’s fielding. 
(iii)  Assisting the MOF (its fiscal policy and budget departments) continuously in the 
general review of the operational aspects of the Budget Law and providing general 
comments,  especially  regarding  technical  PFM  issues  and  the  drafting  of 
implementing decrees for the Budget Law in areas to be mutually identified, to 
ensure coherence between the MTFF and MTEF processes and the Budget Law. 
(iv)  Assisting  the  PEMSP  implementation  committee,  the  project  director,  and  the 
project  coordinators  in  technical  PFM  matters,  including  MTFF  and  MTEF 
methodology. 
(v)  Assisting the team leader in preparing operational guidelines, updating the manual, 
and addressing technical issues in support of MTFF and MTEF implementation.  
(vi)  Assisting the team leader in finalizing the capacity development plan, designing 
capacity and skills improvement indicators, gathering baseline data regarding staff 
skills, and preparing and implementing training programs, workshops, and seminars.  
(vii)   Guiding the implementation of the existing automated simple-to-use fiscal planning 
models and database systems. 
(viii)  Conducting  policy  dialogue  with  senior  MOF  management  (including  the  vice 
minister  of  finance)  and  holding  extensive  discussions  and  workshops  with 
stakeholders and development partners, to build consensus and ownership on the 
MTFF and MTEF and related budget frameworks.  
(ix)  Assisting the team leader in drafting the agenda for open forums, in identifying 
resource persons, and in planning and organizing the open forums in coordination 
with the Government and ADB. 
(x)  Assisting the team leader in, and providing regular inputs to, the preparation of the 
inception, midterm, and draft final reports; preparing progress reports for inclusion in 
the team progress reports to be prepared by the team leader as required in their

14  Appendix 3 
area of expertise and specialization; and assisting the team leader in supervising 
and monitoring TA progress. 
(xi)  Assisting ADB missions with related activities. 
B.  National Consultants 
1.  Fiscal Management Specialist (24 person-months) 
4.  The  national  fiscal  management  specialist  will  have  an  extensive  background  and 
specialization in economics, finance, or related fields, and a sound understanding of relevant 
issues facing PFM reforms in the Lao PDR. The specialist will possess (i) extensive experience in 
financial or fiscal management and proficiency in English, and (ii) expertise in and aptitude for 
computer software and database management systems. Adequate experience in working with 
international consultants and the Government is an advantage.  
5.  The tasks will include (i) assisting the international consultants in all aspects outlined in the 
international consultants’ terms of reference; (ii) gathering and analyzing information and data on 
the budget cycle process, on roles and responsibilities relating to budget preparation within MOF 
departments, line ministries, and provinces and translating these into English; (iii) reviewing MOF 
budget legislation, guidelines, circulars, and other budget-related documents and summarizing 
them for international consultants, and conducting research on topics assigned by the team leader; 
(iv) coordinating with operational budget department and policy department staff and collecting 
information required for TA activities; (v) assisting the national software development specialist in 
performing user tests on developed computer spreadsheets and software and database systems, 
including analyzing stakeholders’ needs and acting as liaison between users and the national 
software  specialist;  (vi)  acting  as  backup  to  the  national  software  development  specialist  in 
providing technical information technology (IT) support to users; (vii) contributing to the design of 
capacity  development  and  training  modules  as  assigned  by  the  team  leader;  (viii) organizing 
training programs, discussions, and workshops as assigned by the team leader; and (ix) supporting 
the  international  consultants  and  ADB  missions  in  preparing  relevant  materials,  including 
translating documents and interpreting  discussions, and providing technical support to MOF, 
selected sector ministries at the central level and provinces, and BOL in the tasks required to 
implement the MTFF and MTEF process. The specialist will work closely with and report to the 
international team leader.  
2.  Software Development Specialist (8 person-months) 
6.  The national software development specialist will have the requisite experience, proficiency, 
and  qualifications  in  developing  computer  software  and  database  management  systems,  or 
customizing off-the-shelf software packages, preferably for PFM purposes. The specialist should 
be proficient in English, and have experience of working with international consultants and the 
Government. This specialist’s tasks will include: (i) undertaking extensive consultations with the 
relevant government departments on their automation needs, to assist in providing automation 
support  for  improved  fiscal  planning  and  budgeting;  (ii)  supporting  training  in  the  automated 
spreadsheet and database models in the Lao language, for the implementation of the MTFF and 
MTEF frameworks and tools already developed, and ensuring compatibility with the existing data 
architecture and file structures of MOF’s accounting and treasury departments; (iii) designing and 
supporting  online  database  interface  and  links  to  the  various  related  departments  (budget, 
accounting, and treasury departments) within MOF in the area of fiscal planning and expenditure 
management; (iv) drafting the specifications for IT equipment to be procured through this project, 
installing the computers and related equipment, installing the developed spreadsheet models and

Appendix 3  15 
automated database management systems, and assisting in implementation; (v) continuing the 
development of software, providing technical IT assistance on the basis of regular discussions with 
MOF user departments during implementation, to enhance the application of the computer systems; 
(vi) preparing user manuals (in both Lao and in English) to guide MOF staff in the use of the 
software and spreadsheet models developed; (vii) assisting in the preparation of materials for 
training, and conducting training programs in the automated models as assigned by the team 
leader; (viii) providing inputs to progress reports for incorporation in the team’s progress reports to 
be prepared by the team leader; and (ix) organizing meetings, discussions, and workshops and 
supporting the international consultants and ADB missions in organizing relevant documents and 
materials, including translating documents and interpreting discussions pertaining to automation 
and software development.
